text: {{Infobox writer | name = Marina Tsvetaeva | image = Marina Tsvetaeva.jpg | pseudonym = | birth_name = Marina Ivanovna Tsvetaeva | birth_date = | birth_place = Moscow, Russian Empire | death_date = | death_place = Yelabuga, Tatar ASSR, Soviet Union | occupation = Poet and writer | spouse = Sergei Efron | children = 3 | education = Sorbonne, Paris | movement = Russian symbolism | genre = | notableworks = | subject = | signature = Tsvetaeva signature 1941.jpg }} Marina Ivanovna Tsvetaeva (; 31 August 1941) was a Russian-Soviet poet. Her work is thought to be some of the greatest in twentieth century Russian literature."Tsvetaeva, Marina Ivanovna" Who's Who in the Twentieth Century. Oxford University Press, 1999. ==Life== She lived through and wrote of the Russian Revolution of 1917 and the Moscow famine that followed it. In an attempt to save her daughter Irina from starvation, she placed her in a state orphanage in 1919, where she died of hunger. Tsvetaeva left Russia in 1922 and lived with her family in increasing poverty in Paris, Berlin and Prague before returning to Moscow in 1939. Her husband Sergei Efron and her daughter Ariadna Efron (Alya) were arrested on espionage charges in 1941; her husband was executed. Tsvetaeva committed suicide by hanging hereself in 1941. ==Books of Tsvetaeva poetry in English translation== * Marina Tsvetaeva: Selected Poems, trans. Elaine Feinstein.
